docs.lead_paragraph: The announcement came a day after a cost analysis showed the bill meeting President Obama’s requirements.

headline.main: Health Care Bill Gets Green Light in Cost Analysis
headline.print_headline: Health Care Bill Gets Green Light in Cost Analysis

docs.snippet: The announcement came a day after a cost analysis showed the bill meeting President Obama’s requirements.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: If a 20 percent discount on your health insurance premium is good, then a 30 percent discount must be better, right? But what if the bigger discount is tied to health goals you might not be able to meet? Some patient advocacy groups are wary of provisions in Congressional health care legislation that would let employers and insurers offer premium discounts of as much as 50 percent to employees in workplace ''wellness'' programs who meet specific health targets, like keeping their weight, cholesterol and blood pressure within healthy ranges.
docs.abstract: Some patient advocacy groups are wary of provisions in health care reform measure that would let employers and insurers offer premium discounts of as much as 50 percent to employees in workplace 'wellness' programs who meet specific targets; under current law, discounts can be no greater than 20 percent of total premium; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Senate Finance Committee on track to approve its health care legislation on Tuesday, Democratic leaders are turning to the tricky task of melding that bill with an alternate measure approved by the health committee in July. There are some big differences, both in policy and cost.
docs.abstract: Democratic leaders are faced with task of melding Senate Finance Committee health care bill with alternate measure approved by Health Committee in July; there are big differences in policy and cost, including proposal for public option written into Health Committee bill but not Finance Committee bill; Sen Tom Harkin, who chairs Health Committee, cites poll numbers that majority of Americans support public option; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Thursday that House Democrats were considering a ''windfall profits tax'' on insurance companies to help pay for legislation that would provide coverage to most of the uninsured. The idea, she said, is to capture some of the profits that insurance companies might reap if the government required nearly everyone to have insurance and subsidized premiums for millions of low- and middle-income people.

headline.main: Democrats Are Considering Additional Tax on Insurers

docs.abstract: House Democrats are considering 'windfall profits tax' on health insurance companies that would help pay for coverage to most uninsured; idea is to capture some profits that insurance companies might reap if government requires nearly everyone to have insurance and offers subsidies to low- and middle-income people; Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid says bill has gained momentum from Congressional Budget Office report that says bill drafted by Finance Committee will provide coverage to 29 million people while reducing deficits over next decade by $81 billion (M)

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: Organized labor is stepping up its push to have a public insurance option in the health care legislation. More than 125 union leaders from 27 states have arrived in Washington to meet with senators and House members who are sitting on the fence about the public option -- a government-run insurance plan -- and other matters.
docs.abstract: More than 125 union leaders descend on Washington to lobby for public option in health care reform measure; AFL-CIO says leaders will deliver more than 42,000 letters to lawmakers; has emailed hundreds of thousands of members, urging them to express support for public option (M)
docs.snippet: Organized labor is stepping up its push to have a public insurance option in the health care legislation.      More than 125 union leaders from 27 states have arrived in Washington to meet with senators and House members who are sitting on the fence...

docs.lead_paragraph: With the Senate Finance Committee on track to approve its health care legislation next Tuesday, Democratic leaders are turning to the tricky task of melding that bill with an alternate measure approved by the Senate's health committee in July. There are some big differences, both in policy and cost.

headline.main: As Senate Melds Health Bills, Harkin Will Insist on Public Option

docs.lead_paragraph: First it was Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Now concern is growing that another government mortgage giant might teeter, just as the nation's housing market is stabilizing.

headline.main: Is F.H.A. the Next Shoe to Drop?
